claim: Cancer can cause excess adrenaline production.

supporting.text: Certain tumors, such as pheochromocytomas, are known to produce excess adrenaline and related hormones.

attacks.text: Certain tumors, such as pheochromocytomas, are known to produce excess adrenaline and related hormones.
Pheochromocytomas are rare, accounting for less than 0.2% of all cancers, so this does not generalize to most cancers.
Even rare cancers are still cancers, so the claim remains technically correct for at least some cases.
Adrenaline production requires specific neuroendocrine differentiation that most carcinomas lack.
Metastatic small cell lung cancer has been shown to occasionally produce catecholamines including adrenaline.

supporting.text: Neuroendocrine tumors can secrete catecholamines, including adrenaline, leading to hormonal imbalances.

attacks.text: Neuroendocrine tumors can secrete catecholamines, including adrenaline, leading to hormonal imbalances.
Not all neuroendocrine tumors secrete catecholamines; some are non-functional and do not cause hormonal imbalances.
Functional neuroendocrine tumors that secrete catecholamines are well-documented in medical literature, supporting the original argument.
Excess adrenaline production is rare in most common cancers, limiting the generalizability of the claim.
While rare in common cancers, neuroendocrine tumors are a recognized subset where adrenaline excess is clinically significant.

supporting.text: Adrenaline production can be stimulated by cancer-related stress responses, including pain and metabolic demands.

attacks.text: Adrenaline production can be stimulated by cancer-related stress responses, including pain and metabolic demands.
Not all cancers cause significant pain or metabolic stress, limiting the generality of this argument.
Adrenaline production is more commonly linked to acute stress responses rather than chronic conditions like cancer.
Certain aggressive cancers (e.g., neuroendocrine tumors) are well-documented to directly stimulate adrenaline production.
Even non-aggressive cancers can indirectly elevate adrenaline through psychological distress in patients.

supporting.text: Metastatic cancers affecting the adrenal glands may disrupt normal hormone regulation, including adrenaline secretion.

attacks.text: Metastatic cancers affecting the adrenal glands may disrupt normal hormone regulation, including adrenaline secretion.
Most cancers do not metastasize to the adrenal glands, making this a rare scenario.
Even when cancers affect the adrenal glands, they may not always disrupt adrenaline secretion significantly.
Studies show that adrenal metastases are present in only about 3-4% of cancer cases.
Functional disruption of adrenal glands by metastases is documented in clinical literature, supporting significant hormonal impact when it occurs.

supporting.text: Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with some cancers can cause hormonal disturbances, including elevated adrenaline levels.

attacks.text: Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with some cancers can cause hormonal disturbances, including elevated adrenaline levels.
Paraneoplastic syndromes are rare, occurring in less than 1% of cancer patients, making this an unlikely general explanation for excess adrenaline production.
Even if rare, paraneoplastic syndromes are well-documented causes of hormonal disturbances in oncology literature, supporting their relevance in specific cases.
Most excess adrenaline production is caused by pheochromocytomas or stress responses, not paraneoplastic syndromes.
While pheochromocytomas are more common, the claim does not exclude other causes like paraneoplastic syndromes.
The term 'some cancers' is too vague to assess the clinical significance of this mechanism.
Small-cell lung cancer and neuroendocrine tumors are specifically documented to cause paraneoplastic hormonal effects.
